CE5F343CBE7C41239BE4F8B640505DB9.description: I can make connections throughout United States history to today’s society using major people and events studied throughout the year.

480CB72CB1BE4DA08BA8B1955FB5C48D.description: I can discuss the ways that scientific and technological advancements have created an Information Age and have changed the daily lives of Americans.

77CF49BDF0DB4962AB2B7572E2D4C603.description: I can describe the events of September 11th and list some ways that it changed the United States.

F563CD747D774066A1C0E86A94222EE8.description: I can identify and describe the major political, social, economic, cultural, and scientific events for select decades.

E20A544D166642A7A0AD6774888246E0.description: Students will analyze the major cultural and political events since the 1970s to determine how they shape our lives today.

5C3B40BC83AF48E5A98BA055A3F7484E.description: I can identify the major issues affecting Americans with Disabilities during this time period and explain the conflicts brought about by these issues including IDEA and the American Disabilities Act.

BEA6CE67FAC442F7A7D3EB4ABB56E6B1.description: I can identify the major issues affecting American Indians during this time period and explain the conflicts brought about by these issues including the American Indian Movement and Wounded Knee.

417B6A59AA934F34A173FBF2BD53C24B.description: I can identify the major issues affecting Hispanic Americans during this time period and explain the conflicts brought about by these issues including the Chicano Movement and Cesar Chavez.

B3F60EAF74B341BD910582A9C5DA075F.description: I can identify the major issues affecting the LGBTQ+ community during this time period and explain the conflicts brought about by these issues including the Stonewall Riots and Marriage Equality.

7FEC2DF19C744B1DBA4BC9A9BA8F4DC2.description: I can identify the major issues affecting women during this time period and explain the conflicts brought about by these issues including NOW and the Equal Rights Amendment (ERA).

8097399E693B411BA8CE829C6AAEAD65.description: I can examine the difference between the goals of Martin Luther King Jr and Malcolm X and their methods in achieving those goals in order to demonstrate different ways of fighting for equality.

9089E3B4B6CD4D66ABA332BE5DB70367.description: I can evaluate the success of the local and federal government in addressing issues of the Civil Rights Movement including Brown vs. Board of Education, the Civil Rights Act, and the Voting Rights Act.

F8F6C39ED5524841B434402D4E6A1902.description: I can identify the ways that Americans fought for equality and civil rights including the NAACP, Little Rock Nine, Children’s March, Montgomery Bus Boycott, sit-ins, and the March on Washington.

9B56613348F142868BB8EA348FB07907.description: I can explain how white people protested Black American civil rights efforts in the South through public protest, the Jim Crow laws, the KKK, and violence against Black Americans (lynching).

3F01F54F8D0E4B3AAB6319CED044D88F.description: Students will examine the ways multiple groups of people fought for their rights during the 1950’s and 1960’s to answer the questions: "What does it take to have a successful social movement?" and "Was the Civil Rights Movement successful?"

69A3AA674BBA4974BB8F6F5A6CEC18C8.description: I can examine how some U.S. citizens protested the Vietnam War, including how the music of the 1960’s represented Anti-Vietnam feelings.

69306EF0BEA242FFB4F11B7CF040E38B.description: I can analyze the causes, events, and outcomes of the Vietnam War including Agent Orange, Ho Chi Minh, Tet Offensive, Viet Cong in order to compare and contrast it with earlier conflicts.

E7D57CC724FE4ADF9D32650772490404.description: I can describe America’s domestic reaction to the Cold War, including the Red Scare and McCarthyism and how it affected the United States.

A2058D62D4F845A8BDAF5BBD0498D9BF.description: I can describe how life changed for Americans during the 1950s socially and economically including the growth of the suburbs and changes in technology and culture.

ADBD27E620DC45DC8511403A61FB3F05.description: I can brainstorm the effects of the rising competition between the U.S. and the Soviet Union including the Arms Race, the Space Race, and the Cuban Missile Crisis.

D0CF73390BEE4C18A5F977893A4B81D3.description: I can analyze the U.S. foreign policy during the Cold War including the Marshall Plan, the policy of Containment, the Truman Doctrine, and Domino Theory in order to explain the United States’ involvement in conflicts including proxy wars in Korea and Vietnam.

AE87B082483B4A5B9863CD9DC4F869F2.description: I can describe the political, social, and geographic divisions of the Cold War including the division of Germany, the Iron Curtain, NATO, the Warsaw Pact, the Berlin Airlift, and the Berlin Wall

9316EEB014594366BE4C3EFD571CC755.description: I can explain how World War II’s aftermath lead to the Cold War and the key countries involved in the Cold War.

FDDCE85834F04217A2742D3FA64A1E56.description: I can define capitalism and communism and explore the advantages and disadvantages between the two systems.

865207630C3D42319042D668F0CEFF50.description: Students will analyze the events of the Cold War to determine its social and political effects on the United States.

5080C98DEC8043DF81D004943545457D.description: I can suggest ways to address and prevent genocides, past and present.

F0622A227C6A47FABF45404D1696DD3E.description: I can apply the stages of genocide in multiple genocides throughout history including the Holocaust, Armenian Genocide, the Famine-Genocide in Ukraine, Cambodia, Bosnia, Rwanda, and/or Sudan.

133B8BA1B48C418A9322953FAF950B77.description: I can describe the systematic nature of the Holocaust including Nazi ideology, anti-semitism, propaganda, the Nuremberg Laws, ghettos and concentration & death camps.

97C5D0E8CE034DED92B2532F16E96D76.description: Students will analyze the events and impact of the Holocaust and other genocides in order to reflect on the stages of genocide, how to prevent genocide, and to develop plans to address modern genocide.

DB40583189A44A3FBD12F5B41409B671.description: I can analyze the aftermath of WWII to determine its influence on the world map and global political institutions like the United Nations.

E8B7CAA00CA54114AB9066D92740ADB1.description: I can explain the reasons for the dropping of atomic bombs on Japan and its short and long-term effects.

82CDB021709C46E5B7D664E07C39B9F3.description: I can describe the reasons given for interning the Japanese Americans and the effect it had on the United States.

419C4EEE297D434CBF385DF2E74A2FEC.description: I can evaluate the effects of WWII on the U.S., including rationing, the use of propaganda and the role of women in order to explain how US citizens supported the war effort at home.

298B533DD2934F0D8353A1A59C6A1753.description: I can identify important people and their roles including Douglas MacArthur, Harry Truman, and Hideki Tojo.

42C97A2873C64E47A626138ECA7C9A4E.description: I can identify and explain important conflicts from WWII in the Pacific including Pearl Harbor, Hiroshima and Nagasaki, island hopping, and VJ Day.

E81BFFE011AC42359DDA025225B1BEE2.description: I can locate Japan and the Pacific Islands on a map in order to explain the concept of island hopping.

D8BBE8903A8B45E3858D3684200F0E1B.description: I can describe the causes of Japanese expansion and the order in which it occurred.

4FFDF677ADA240D4813DA952789CC73E.description: I can identify important people and their roles including Winston Churchill, Joseph Stalin, Dwight D. Eisenhower, Franklin D. Roosevelt.

7CC0946A025C4A56A3F0587A7EB116EF.description: I can identify and explain important conflicts from WWII in Europe, including D-Day, the Battle of the Bulge, and VE Day.

160CA8242422467881B738DAAA9C050A.description: I can describe the expansion of Germany across Europe.

72B0A58C82DD47D383FA0DE7FF026E5E.description: I can locate and identify the Axis and Allied countries involved in WWII on a world map.

DDE2A88C9BFA44EB90216341720023CF.description: I can list the causes of the war in Europe.

0A48CC07361244F1AA7360A4FB8022BE.description: I can define the term fascism and identify how fascist leaders came to power in Europe before WWII including Benito Mussolini and Adolf Hitler.

F4EF035B28E846D0909AD0297D7C895B.description: I can contextualize the situation in Germany after World War I including the Weimar Republic that set the stage for Adolf Hitler’s rise to power.

E8D7030CC3AD44BDBFEFBC510D586D08.description: Students will analyze the causes, events, and outcomes of World War II to explain how global war affected the United States and ultimately how global war can be avoided in the future.

401937B7348145B9A7B4CF6561092FE2.description: I can analyze the Treaty of Versailles and the Fourteen Points to determine their impact on the European community.

3894B4D82B8C49CC8157251E131DC38A.description: I can describe how combat technology evolved during WWI including new weapons, trench warfare, and the use of air power.

29B899D852644B939097D18F4E8BDB45.description: I can describe how the war affected life on the home front for Americans including the four themes of U.S. WWI Propaganda and the Espionage Act.

186CEBEA65B545928BA303E967245BD0.description: I can analyze the reasons the U.S. got involved in WWI and how U.S. involvement affected the war.

12683791D0C74CF4BB91B9E0E561097D.description: I can recognize major events and outcomes of World War I and how the war changed Europe.

9DFABF6C86D04852B20B18FB668BAED6.description: I can identify and explain the main causes that lead to the beginning of World War I.

5D85B8B8E9FA4BC69763FF7A1B31C201.description: I can locate and identify the countries involved in WWI on a European map.

F921559DE54F40EC86962EC9F6C03086.description: I can identify and describe the causes, events, and outcomes of the Spanish-American War.

6F1C5CDF6E2F4E469C063403D9874285.description: I can define the terms militarism, nationalism, imperialism, neutrality, and manifest destiny.

2408D616C6CD4C60B4BF6A658CC8A802.description: Students will analyze the key events leading up to and including World War I to explore the United State's changing role in global conflict.

F8D42FAB2CF2448191568B9D23CDEC68.description: I can evaluate the success of the New Deal as it pertains to different groups of Americans, especially the Federal Housing Administration's practice of redlining.

BCA689B23E244B7A9A43DF7DA52AE995.description: I can list and explain some of the changes that the New Deal brought to the relationship between citizens and the government including, social security, “Relief, Recovery and Reform” the Tennessee Valley Authority, and the FDIC.

2000A58CA9B94801B3B3058170FEEDDE.description: I can describe the way that the relationship between citizens and government changed during this time period, as reflected in the philosophies and policies of Herbert Hoover and Franklin Roosevelt.

1E4BAA40CA0B4EA5B33CA669AFE94209.description: I can describe how the Depression affected individual lives and society as a whole (breadlines, unemployment, Dust Bowl, international depression)

3598135DBA614A6A8A8AAC46B252D346.description: I can explain the causes of the Great Depression including buying on credit, underconsumption, overproduction, the stock market crash and banking policies

7A34504952634283BBBA94407A9FA831.description: Students will investigate the causes and outcomes of the Great Depression in order to come to a conclusion about how economic downturns should be addressed.

ADC9011E1CB841C5AD41FFE60B883D9B.description: I can analyze the policies of Presidents Harding and Coolidge in order to determine how they reflected America’s changing mood.

11B19E23311B47DFBAE50D5F2E07AB11.description: I can explain how the stock market impacted the U.S. economy and the effect this growth had on the American consumer including causes and results of Stock Market Crashes (1929 and 2008)

E5070510E808492C81CA6660E19B04B8.description: I can define consumerism explain how technological advancements in transportation and entertainment changed the American "standard of living" during the 1920s.

8F35F528F56B4A6EBB66BE02CD1E99F2.description: I can describe explosions of intellectual and musical culture during the 1920s including the Harlem Renaissance and Jazz musicians like Louis Armstrong, Bessie Smith, and Duke Ellington.

501DF8C0AD66455B8E1DF180661F337B.description: I can identify how the role of women changed in the 1920’s including flappers.

E5523546EC4E4DCBA2046784F163C86D.description: I can define prohibition and explain its effects on American society, including speakeasies, bootlegging, political corruption, and organized crime.

21A2C57814724B06A838FF9D1F9071DD.description: Students will analyze the changes that occurred during the 1920’s to determine how American lifestyle and culture were impacted.

1772021937AB40F99C6438D3C524D5C2.description: I can analyze the policies and views of the three progressive presidents, Theodore Roosevelt (labor unions, wilderness conservation, the Square Deal), William Howard Taft, and Woodrow Wilson to determine if they were Progressive by the standards of the time.

CCEB624669004A3ABF9AA62E63C1BAE7.description: I can determine how the Progressive Era affected the lives of women and other groups in the late 1800s including The Suffrage Movement, Temperance Crusade, 18th and 19th Amendments.

01D2B7E971AC402D96B01C5E7974EE2E.description: I can describe the Women's Suffrage Movement and investigate ways in which Americans argued for and against women's suffrage.

646F16981E7C4D2291BE4F74CA23F7A5.description: I can identify how racial tension affected the United States during the early 1900s including the Great Migration, Sundown Towns, the Red Summer of 1919 and the Tulsa Race Massacre of 1921.

69D1616E3C6742F797AA21F0D80F1651.description: I can compare and contrast how leaders of minority groups reacted to discrimination during this time period including Booker T. Washington and W.E.B. DuBois.

DCA900BFA48C44128DDC57EC5CCEA067.description: I can explain how the Progressives fought corruption in government, including the Pendleton Act, Sherman Antitrust Act, the 17th Amendment.

DFBEDC01B83F44A187D5B4275BB3AC78.description: I can explain how the Progressives fought corruption in business and government, including muckrakers (Upton Sinclair, Ida Tarbell, Jacob Riis, Ida B. Wells etc.).

033D13BDB3854FA996CF247199E2E88F.description: Students will analyze political and social reform during the late 1800s and early 1900s (The Progressive Era) in order to evaluate whether or not life improved for Americans during this time period.

4D7660D537B648D49B8A900091E4AB60.description: I can describe life for immigrants in the United States, including settlement houses, tenements, Nativism, assimilation, the Chinese Exclusion Act, and the Emergency Quota Act.

B661BEF08D5B422AA1B34F97D323BAB6.description: I can describe the journey to the United States, including immigrant experiences at Ellis Island and Angel Island.

BBBD78E0664644E3907DDBA85C6F7323.description: I can list push and pull factors that led to Italian, Russian, Jewish, Chinese, and Mexican immigration.

B880AC544E764BE6AB96154797AE469D.description: Students will analyze the experience and contributions of immigrants in the United States during the late 1800’s and early 1900’s in order to explore immigration's effect on the United States.

E8FCBA0A36574D138F51BB5C0157E366.description: I can analyze major labor conflicts of this time period to determine how they impacted the lives of American workers, including the Haymarket Square Affair, Homestead Strike, Pullman Strike, and the Triangle Factory Fire.

2276C292BBA14C4B90E6920FD685AD2B.description: I can examine why workers formed labor unions in the middle to late 1800’s, the obstacles people faced in creating unions, and the effect unions had on workers’ rights.

7A93D1D58CE343B891B371AC96751823.description: I can describe how Industrialization brought about the growth of cities and compare and contrast the living conditions in cities for the poor, middle class, and rich including tenements.

E67299DEA3EE4CD9A51123D198694A6C.description: I can identify examples of political corruption during the Gilded Age and how this corruption impacted society.

509DFF346EB548BCB4C7687322A97E5F.description: I can analyze the concepts of Robber Barons versus Captains of Industry and evaluate how these concepts could be applied to Americans

E21724EA55DB4DB9A2F69617301DA649.description: I can describe how Americans built fortunes in the oil and steel industries, including the important businessmen of the time period such as Andrew Carnegie and John D. Rockefeller.

ED63062D4C6044FF98298CDAC9FEACC7.description: I can define monopoly, trust, laissez-faire economy, Gilded Age, and Robber Baron.

9F9D02F636C54909A1A94226480AF987.description: I can explain how inventions revolutionized society in the mid-late 1800s including railroad expansion, the assembly line, light bulb, steel, and telegraph

447D5A35343448359D9E2CA7240BB043.description: Students will analyze the advancements and conflict in society during the late 1800s in order to describe how the United States changed during this time period.

5F946709F08846768C37A8F736747B89.description: Explain the main goals of Reconstruction (physical rebuilding, reunification of the states, and ensuring rights for newly freed slaves), describe the purpose of the 13th, 14th, and 15th amendments to the U.S. Constitution, and identify other important social and political consequences of Reconstruction (such as the Freedman’s Bureau, sharecropping, black codes, hate groups including the Ku Klux Klan, poll taxes, segregation/Jim Crow laws, and the Supreme Court’s Plessy v. Ferguson decision).

6AA5151DB89249569EB30B591DF65095.description: Analyze the reasons for the North’s victory and the social, economic, and political effects of the Civil War (including the effects of the war on soldiers, civilians, the environment, the power of the federal government, and future warfare).

CA74ED9845C0406C8386D249A058E36A.description: Examine the role of women, African Americans, new technology (such as iron-clad ships and the telegraph), and Sherman’s March to the Sea/”total war” on the outcome of the Civil War.

968A8B905DB142FBBC7A504ED9106B5D.description: Discuss the main ideas and effects of Abraham Lincoln’s Emancipation Proclamation (1863), Gettysburg Address (1863), and First and Second Inaugural Addresses.

1D749F0A08704FB5B2E0CF6247CAD311.description: Explain how each of the following events affected the outcome of the Civil War: Fort Sumter, Bull Run, Antietam, Gettysburg, Vicksburg, Appomattox Court House, and Lincoln’s assassination.

7F75F77A66BF4C7193E876EA662B9C0D.description: Explain how each of the following people influenced the outcome of the Civil War: Jefferson Davis, Ulysses S. Grant, William Tecumseh Sherman, and Robert E. Lee.

62CF8123BF5C4790A467C27ACF654D53.description: Identify Union, Confederate, and Border States on a map of North America at the beginning of the war, and explain the significance of the Border States.

D28CC5EBE91D46949B5471DB10DCC387.description: Define secession, Confederacy, and civil war and identify the strengths, weaknesses, and goals of the North and the South at the beginning of the war.

1292CFFE855349869225A3F1FE0238EE.description: Students will analyze the key issues, people, and events of the Civil War to determine why and how the North won the war and describe the main policies and consequences of Reconstruction.

05C9F2FB4F154F5CA4A0B5A16E147730.description: Summarize the problem, solution, and effects of each of the following social and political developments and describe how each of these developments contributed to increasing sectional conflict as a result of the debate over slavery, states’ rights, westward expansion, and the balance of power in Congress: (a) the Missouri Compromise (1820), (b) the Compromise of 1850, publication of Uncle Tom's Cabin (1851-1852), (c) the Kansas-Nebraska Act (1854), (d) the Dred Scott decision by the U.S. Supreme Court (1857), and (e) the election of Abraham Lincoln (1860).

590FF1CD831D4DB5A19E48952DEBF3B2.description: Compare the experiences and rights of enslaved African Americans in the South with those of (a) free African Americans in the South and the North, and (b) “wage slaves” in the North.

A00F67DF57374D6B9B623713837AC542.description: Define abolition and identify key events and people in the abolitionist movement including (a) how the Second Great Awakening contributed to the abolitionist movement, (b) early attempts by the federal government to limit slavery (Northwest Ordinances, 1808 ban of foreign slave trade, American Colonization Society), (c) the roles played by key abolitionists (William Lloyd Garrison, the Grimke sisters, Frederick Douglass, Sojourner Truth, and Harriet Tubman), (d) strategies used by slaves to resist slavery (passive resistance, the Underground Railroad, outright rebellions such as Nat Turner’s rebellion), and (e) Southern efforts to preserve slavery (slave codes).

DC55A4D40B3A4F75AC4AEEB0D5A6AA29.description: Define antebellum, sectionalism, and Industrial Revolution and describe important changes in the economy of the antebellum North and South that contributed to disagreements along sectional lines, including the causes and positive and negative effects of (a) the expansion of the South’s agrarian economy and the growth of cotton as a cash crop as a result of the invention of the cotton gin, (b) industrialization, immigration, changing roles for women (“Lowell Girls”), the growth of cities, and advances in transportation in the North, and (c) inventions that made farming profitable and encouraged people to settle in the Midwest.

F83DC3AA08BD4CA68EE80AB527616DC4.description: Students will analyze the social, economic, geographic, and political changes in the North and the South and key political events between 1808 and 1861 to determine how those developments increasingly divided the United States across sectional lines and led to the outbreak of the Civil War.

EF89ED1DEE5E4CB499B902FE9152304D.description: Describe the role in westward expansion and the legacy of each of the following groups: pioneer women, Mormons, Forty-Niners, and the Chinese.

7A282645F21D436C9952D094819C2635.description: Use a map of North America to demonstrate America’s expansion through 1854, and describe why and how the United States acquired the Louisiana Territory, Florida, Texas, Oregon Territory, Mexican Cession (Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo), and the Gadsden Purchase.

E91510A0F3FD4CBDB18AAFCF1BFB1E7F.description: Define Jacksonian Democracy and describe how Jackson’s presidency changed America socially, economically, geographically, and politically (including the causes and effects of Jackson’s election and approach to governing, the nullification crisis, his veto of the National Bank charter, and the Indian Removal Act).

650E8813F64F4E4E85A7208D2C379FFF.description: Define Manifest Destiny, describe the social, economic, and political push and pull factors that prompted Americans to move westward, and explain the role of technology in encouraging and supporting this westward movement including new communication and transportation methods.

15385A281C624C2DA15A05FF36DE2253.description: Students will explain why and how the United States added to its territory in the first half of the 19th Century and evaluate whether the benefits of westward expansion outweigh the negative consequences.

1EF9EB2B02E84BF28A4A144481ED632B.description: Describe the “Era of Good Feelings, identify the goals of Henry Clay’s American System and the 3 parts of of Clay’s plan, and explain how the plan both increased the power of the federal government and gave rise to regional divisions between the North and the South.

FACA1E816EF347CA8427312CE4A93FE6.description: Define isolationism and embargo, and describe the development of U.S. foreign policy from 1789 through 1825. These developments include the causes, key events, and effects of (a) the Battle of Fallen Timbers, (b) war between England and France (including Jay’s Treaty, the XYZ Affair, Jefferson’s embargo, and the War of 1812), (c) the Barbary War, and (d) the Monroe Doctrine.

24812CD643854728B8042403CB314D08.description: Compare and contrast a market economy and a mixed economy, explain the purpose of a tariff, identify the domestic economic and political challenges facing the new nation, and analyze conflicting solutions to these problems that gave rise to the development of two political parties conflicting solutions to these problems that gave rise to the development of two political parties governments, the Whiskey Rebellion, economic policy such as the need for a national bank and tariffs, the Alien and Sedition Act, and the Louisiana Purchase).

E1244D61868D4A3AA1574C39BDB6221B.description: Define precedent and describe the significance of precedents established during the presidency of George Washington, including the main ideas and importance of Washington’s Farewell Address.

07C1DD9FB90744ABA45E1040C2A61169.description: Students will examine key decisions by George Washington during his presidency, conflicts that gave rise to political parties, and the development of U.S. foreign policy to describe how America grew and changed between 1789 and 1825.

4EC5682B206A4FDCB3A0FCD6CA55C0A6.description: Define “proportional representation.” Identify the advantages (strengths) and disadvantages (weaknesses) of (a) America’s two-party system, and (b) a multi-party system where lawmakers are elected by proportional representation.

D12F38E6D96740CF9EB0B5D7F45C1AA2.description: Explain why third parties form, list third parties in the U.S. today, describe some effects of third parties on elections, and explain ballot access issues that make it difficult for third party candidates to win elections in America.

53C3B572088A47A09CD41262C295B821.description: Define “party platform” and explain the difference between valence and position issues.

A263B6EBD957448EB9BCDA4DF73DE241.description: List and explain the roles/main functions of political parties.

7FDEA3D0BFB140AF9CCCE5B28C53BA1D.description: Define “political party,” describe the purpose of political parties, and explain why people organize and join political parties. Identify America’s two major political parties and the symbol for each party. Explain why some Americans identify as “independent.”

E7E43CA5170A4BC6B67B90FE0FCE2593.description: Students will evaluate whether America’s 2-party system enhances (helps) or endangers (hurts) our democracy.

04572B6A31434B87A1C75AF0C91637A7.description: Compare the U.S. Constitution and the Illinois Constitution to determine principles of democracy common to both levels of government and recognize differences between the federal and state governments.

6318E700DE0F45F6999A41903FA21450.description: Explain why and how the U.S. Constitution divides power between the federal government and the states, and recognize examples of enumerated, reserved, concurrent, and prohibited powers.

54FF443D791449438A8E43AB962AE6DD.description: Compare the duties and responsibilities of American citizens to participate in, monitor, and bring about changes in their government over time including voting by secret ballot (“Australian Ballot system”) and the symbolic elements and proper display of the American flag.

C99118DD16D44EE8AB00180C8BAB0BDB.description: Defend the Constitution’s division of power among the three branches of the federal government, identify the branches, describe the organization and operation of the legislative, executive, and judicial branches, and demonstrate the principle of checks and balances built into the Constitution’s “elastic clause” and the Constitutional process of lawmaking, amendment, and judicial review.

E327453D1E0449288326706E4166B450.description: Describe the importance of the Preamble and each of the six “big ideas” of the U.S. Constitution and provide examples of how the U.S. Constitution reflects and preserves these basic principles of American democracy. These “big ideas” include federalism, popular sovereignty, representative government, separation of powers, checks and balances, and limited government to protect individual rights.

673C579879144979A646A0D10259DA0B.description: Analyze the main disagreements among delegates to the Constitutional Convention to determine the key compromises included in the U.S. Constitution and explain why the delegates made these compromises (interests of large and small states and the Great Compromise, slavery and the 3/5ths Representation Compromise, the Executive Branch, and the protection of individual rights that led to publication of The Federalist Papers and the Bill of Rights).

203EE38A2A5C4732B1416373E677890B.description: Define Articles of Confederation, constitution, inflation, recession, depression, GDP, budget, deficit, debt, and income/sales/property taxes. Explain why the Second Continental Congress intentionally created a weak central government under the Articles of Confederation, and identify the strengths and weaknesses of the Article that led the delegates at the Constitutional Convention to write a new constitution instead of simply editing the Articles (including the causes and effects of Shay’s Rebellion).

F4D1450DD63B4134A8B7E3A7F3B7DE5F.description: Students will explain the guiding principles and framework of the American political system and identify how citizens participate in it.

4681211150A4452B8E4472DDC4E96BE4.description: Describe how women, African Americans, Native Americans, and foreign support affected the outcome of the Revolutionary War and discuss the political, social, and economic outcomes of the Revolutionary War.

197297832313455893A5F7D723140A0C.description: Evaluate the following battles and events during the Revolutionary War to determine how each development affected the outcome of the war and the future of the Americas: Trenton, Saratoga, winter at Valley Forge, Yorktown, and the signing of the Treaty of Paris.

12234EFCC27B4D6FAAD691AD4FBEA292.description: Explain the role of key political and military leaders in winning the war against England (Benjamin Franklin, George Washington, Marquis de Lafayette, Baron Friedrich von Steuben, and Casimir Pulaski).

736875D15AAE4A65B41A4C2323BEB059.description: Assess the strengths and weaknesses of the British and American armies at the beginning of the war.

228577B3DCBA430D9DBA62141CA2E61A.description: Define “revolutionary,” explain the effect on the colonial independence movement of the King’s rejection of the Olive Branch Petition and the publication of Common Sense by Thomas Paine, and analyze the effects of the Declaration of Independence on the relationship of the colonies to England and as a set of guiding principles on which to base a new and independent government.

145B539B81C846178E9089D6E426670F.description: Explain how events in the colonies led to the outbreak of the Revolutionary War including the events (a) between 1767 and 1774 that built colonial unity (the Townshend Acts, Boston Massacre, Boston Tea Party and the Intolerable Acts) and (b) between 1775 and 1776 that led to a call to arms (battles of Lexington and Concord, and Breed’s Hill/Bunker Hill).

2AA51171F2DD42ACBE58723CC5394D53.description: Define perspective, Loyalist, and Patriot. Describe the causes and effects of (a) the Navigation Acts, and (b) the French and Indian War. Describe why British policies from 1763-1765 caused tension between England and her colonists in the Americas based on the colonists’ concern about “taxation without representation” (the Proclamation of 1763, the Quartering Act, and the Stamp Act).

E14CA150C6924A289826C512DC31FAE5.description: Students will analyze the social, economic, and political interests of American colonists to determine the causes of the American Revolution and the key issues, people, and events of the Revolutionary War to determine how America secured its independence.

CA6C9701444B4E858B6DF0ED19DB1722.description: Compare the role of climate and natural resources, religion, purpose for founding, and key founders of the colonies in each of the three colonial regions to determine (a) why and how each region developed differently, and (b) how these factors shaped the development of an American identify.

33DCAF1B949A45FC8B33477658DA4E06.description: Identify the key ideas of Magna Carta and the Mayflower Compact and describe how the principles of limited government and representative government from these documents took root in the American identify, including New England town meetings and colonial legislatures such as the Virginia House of Burgesses.

057C972487F1421CB4347E9FFA6EC40E.description: Analyze the views of English settlers and Native Americans on the ownership and use of land to determine how these different views affected the relationship between these two groups in Colonial America, including the causes and effects of King Philip’s War.

47D1C3A4D1084FC6B3AF2DCA4D1C7C7B.description: List the original 13 colonies, label the three colonial regions and all 13 colonies on a map, and create a visual to explain Triangular Trade (including the Middle Passage).

AFF6B9F99F1F4FD29A9D255A99E6E3F3.description: Compare the purpose, settlers, and location chosen for the first four English colonies and explain why colonists in these colonies had such different experiences (Roanoke, Jamestown, Plymouth, and Boston).

C09C05E0155746CE8CA8E6082B610639.description: Define colony, indentured servant, representative democracy, and Triangular Trade.

51A8128A3C464BE48286CEB27ED4F902.description: Students will compare the development of the three English colonial regions in North America to identify similarities and differences that affected the growth of each region and the development of an American identity.

566115F326364F04834AABD086793402.description: Evaluate how interactions between Europeans, First Americans, and Africans shaped early American history as the result of the Columbian Exchange and other significant social, cultural, and political changes on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean including (a) the division of the “New World” of the Americans by the “Old World” European powers of Spain, France, the Netherlands, and England, and (b) the positive and negative effects of the Columbian Exchange on each side of the Atlantic, including the effects of the introduction of European diseases to the Americas, the origins of the African slave trade, and changes in the environment of the Americas.

DC1D028B30464442A68B7785446B731B.description: Provide evidence to explain why and how European nations competed to explore, conquer, and colonize new lands and people including (a) the key economic terms of import, export, mercantilism, opportunity cost, and scarcity, (b) events and technological developments that made such European exploration possible, and (c) the desire for “God, glory, and gold.”

B4272436A0FD47CDA08AC6056DC40C74.description: Analyze maps and artifacts to (a) identify where the pre-Columbian Native Americans (the “First Americans”) came from and why and how they migrated over time to the Americas, (b) explain how the the Neolithic Revolution and maize led to permanent communities and the development of unique cultures across the Americas, and (c) gather evidence of distinct, diverse, and increasingly complex cultures that largely resulted from how the First Americans of each region adapted to and modified their environment through innovations in agriculture, resource use, and social structure.

70B0FC708B2A44DDB4A3ACE54A2610E6.description: Students will analyze the reasons for, and evaluate the effects of, European exploration and colonization to determine how interactions between Europeans and Native Americans shaped America’s early history.

8B2E4EF6CAE940879C6E4EDDE18EAAF7.description: Identify key Islamic accomplishments in the areas of science, mathematics, and the arts.

C740B34E3233493A96020325A0A6DB1F.description: Determine the major factors that led to the spread of Islam.

F5625818DB3F462A8676246B841168DA.description: Analyze the significance Muhammad in the development of Islam.

D4CCC1364364411DA95DE8758B9B2D21.description: Explain the origins of Islam (including the location of origin) and describe its fundamental teachings.

DB7355D025BF438C8B06E972E3D1A499.description: Students will describe the rise and spread of Islam to determine its contribution to the ancient and modern world.

1B14962392BB4C0AAE2C154A4D486C95.description: Examine the legacies of Roman architecture, engineering, language, and law to determine their influence on the modern world.

F03E414F8B90427F9C011B9E58B7CB79.description: Identify the economic, political, and social reasons for the decline of the Roman Empire.

FE40A20CBAE341069D40E867B3910FAE.description: Describe the origins and teachings of Christianity and how Christianity changed the Roman Empire.

B0EF29856B7840C8B050D4A20695A271.description: Describe ancient Roman society, including religion, family life, and social classes.

2D452C6F70F24C41AF3B3C86333B294C.description: Identify the events and factors that led to the development of the Roman Empire.

C2EE51CE9D164330897D9C01BD251A46.description: Debate whether Julius Caesar had a positive or negative influence on Rome and its people.

1FDE574E24BA41388762C7B83BED9E67.description: Analyze Roman expansion to determine how it led to social and political conflict.

7BF450FA7F024CBE8C246699BE16EE65.description: Describe the characteristics of the Roman Republic, and compare the Roman Republic to the United States government today.

1BB56D87AFD54870B849C245765FCFD6.description: Summarize the legends and facts that shaped Rome’s history, including the importance of mythical and historical figures.

42DFFD64E2F4462F996678309DBDA1F6.description: Analyze the geographic features of the Italian peninsula in order to explain how geography affected the location of early settlement and supported the rise of civilization.

30B8553F5C2E493BB646EBA193B97644.description: Students will analyze the characteristics of ancient Roman civilization to determine its contributions to the ancient and modern world (including the rise and spread of Christianity).

03AA92C3059042F88C65A9F648AA498E.description: Explain the effects the Silk Road had on global trade, communication, and the spread of religion and culture.

504289ABDF76405EAF4BB6278F98E218.description: Explain the origins and teachings of Legalism, Confucianism, and Taoism, and apply each philosophy to the ancient and modern world.

EF39EC8390D141F698F3A93089305827.description: Describe the characteristics of Chinese social classes and family roles in order to explain their effect on Chinese society.

31DF5798ECCC4F788B90B775F06AD93C.description: Identify the major beliefs of the Shang, Zhou, Qin, and Han dynasties to determine accomplishments in the areas of culture and government.

6D35AEE2B9A646568EAB0DD8F51341ED.description: Analyze the geographic features of China to explain how geography affected the location of early settlement and supported the rise of civilization.

8E0D3CB991924C16B3576C7AE12EB471.description: Students will analyze the characteristics of ancient Chinese civilization to determine its contributions to the ancient and modern world.

DEAA3A6312B24BC283974C91C8B7BE24.description: Analyze the achievements of the Mauryan and Gupta empires to determine their impact on the ancient and modern world.

3B371718807D47A686322FEF4B487018.description: Explain the origins of Buddhism and describe its fundamental teachings.

D1500280EB454B85816AFB512627FE93.description: Explain the origins of Hinduism and describe its fundamental teachings.

1DB58DBEA728412BA0D7B9C2A2380A97.description: Describe the origin and practices of the caste system and explain its impact on Indian society in the ancient and modern world.

9A52B865310B41E09515A73FD217B183.description: Analyze the geography and climate of the Indian subcontinent in order to explain how geography affected the location of early settlement and supported the rise of early cities (Harappa and Mohenjo-daro).

858DC90821A34E9DBC661F669CCB68BE.description: Students will analyze the characteristics of ancient Indian civilization to determine its contributions to the ancient and modern world (including the rise and spread of Hinduism and Buddhism).

BF21A908DC1A4E8288AC8462781293E0.description: Evaluate and defend the legacy and actions of Alexander the Great, and how his actions contributed to the development of a Hellenistic culture.

C40F41C80CF24A948B4F85D02BAA4B89.description: Analyze the contributions of Greek culture in order to show how the Greeks influenced other cultures and the modern world (including the arts, architecture, drama, literature, philosophy, government, mathematics, and sciences).

04CED0FF96064AC6A51487A27E17F922.description: Describe the religion of the ancient Greeks and the role the gods played in Greek daily life.

B5C554E751D0428A9E83AF224134CFB4.description: Explain the causes and effects of the Persian and Peloponnesian Wars.

ED24D4FC4CEC49908F1BC68C28CCE26B.description: Compare and contrast differing philosophies of the Athenians and Spartans in order to describe the differences in beliefs, government, and daily life in these rival city-states.

BF61CDA4E49547D59DE29E47BA164BC7.description: Compare and contrast Athenian "Direct" Democracy and U.S. "Representative" Democracy.

41CAF24C84B946DA829C5680F107B6C5.description: Describe the evolution of different forms of government in Ancient Greece (Monarchy, Oligarchy, Tyranny, and Democracy).

D38FBDCD6EC64CBA8B4ECBF5E05960B0.description: Describe how the idea of Greek citizenship developed in Greek city-states.

FCE4E3A000C3484BB693BC970FC508A0.description: Explain how geography shaped Greek civilization (including the creation of city-states, colonization, and trade).

151DE0B4104E4DB7A840B4F2534587CA.description: Students will analyze the characteristics of ancient Greek civilization to determine its contributions to the ancient and modern world.

87D19F4F04FA4BF6B92D26341C75743F.description: Explain how Judaism survived and developed despite the Jewish Diaspora.

A81E3BB13B7246E8B133F72A3966EFCB.description: Describe the central laws and teachings of Judaism and how they remain influential today.

E4A18C99446A4468BDDE6D0E43CF143C.description: Analyze the significance of the stories of Abraham, Moses, David, and Solomon in the history of the Israelites in order to explain the development of Judaism.

B00B113948684492A8498A9FB3F5CDF0.description: Describe the origins of Judaism as the first monotheistic religion (including the location of origin).

6BB97C8217574BA3B3D4F8B69C5870EC.description: Students will describe the rise and spread of Judaism to determine its contribution to the ancient and modern world.

266FCF0C938240FE9202C2F28EABE19E.description: Describe the governmental structure and important rulers of the Old, Middle, and New Kingdoms.

07375B28E3374B66876138A3FF05D3C9.description: Define pharaoh and analyze the pharaoh’s impact on the pyramids, social structure, daily life, religion, and government of Egypt.

35C8CD85E58A4C51814C83B9AC17B5F0.description: Identify the advancements made by ancient Egyptians in the fields of architecture, medicine, and hieroglyphics.

0848DA8F8662413AB9C301169B15DC12.description: Explain why the social structure of ancient Egypt was organized like a pyramid and the importance of the social structure in society.

34E349FF141843679A65FCBE9F413442.description: Define polytheism and describe the role religion played in Egyptian life.

A5669E8EC199422289A4FDEA991E994F.description: Describe the geographic features of the fertile Nile River Valley to explain why civilization arose there.

3FADD6AA4CD24FFFA18AA56C33DADDE2.description: Evaluate the importance of the Nile River in terms of its economic, geographic, and religious functions.

43499B6F110544448E91472FA9A25F63.description: Students will analyze the characteristics of ancient Egyptian civilization to determine its contribution to the ancient world.

3B8313346B2845DBB6751576C79B3609.description: Describe the rise, influence, and decline of Mesopotamian empires (Akkadians, Babylonians, Assyrians and Chaldeans).

64E7C3810B0D4EA494F8BD01C68C5A4E.description: Define empire and Hammurabi’s Code of Law, and describe how the Babylonian Empire governed their people.

5936F623304641A78198B7962A8C6307.description: Describe the political, social, and economic systems of Sumer to explain why it is considered the first civilization.

569783F476F34204A96960D39232245E.description: List and give examples of the six basic traits of a civilization.

1714C751A82945B4BD0825B734F0E194.description: Analyze the geographic features of the Fertile Crescent in order to explain how geography affected the location of early settlement and supported the rise of civilization.

A2B7629B2C234991AEDF3EE3D9F6F412.description: Students will analyze the social and economic systems, geographic location, and early forms of government of Mesopotamia to explain the growth of civilization and evolution of empires.

69C3C0AE0FE84A87BA3F6A402B424EBD.description: Relate the agricultural revolution (including the impact of food surplus from farming) to population growth and the subsequent development of civilizations.

45DF2E6BAC634E31898F16E642419CC8.description: Explain how and why language, religion, and art developed in Paleolithic communities.

2EBC736CFAE145F596E960E442FC158B.description: Describe life in a hunter-gatherer society (including the development of tools and the use of fire) and give examples of how early humans were able to interact with the environment to support basic needs.

09A2D839B2214CE28B43AAF36F30209C.description: Explain how archaeological discoveries are used to develop and enhance understanding of life prior to written records.

161F426483E34F9CBB0C943DD293FC6F.description: Students will analyze early humans and their interaction with the environment to determine their role in the development of social, economic, and political systems.
